**Answer:**

Expert Systems are knowledge-based systems that were developed under the umbrella of Artificial Intelligence (AI) around mid-1970s [1]. They can be defined as software that performs tasks requiring human expertise, by emulating human knowledge and skill [1]. Expert systems contain specialized knowledge elicited from a domain expert [1]. The general architecture consists of four main components: user interface, explanation facility, working memory, and inference engine [1]. The theoretical foundations of expert systems are based on the concept of IF-THEN rules, which are used to represent human expertise in the knowledge base [1]. Inferencing can be done through forward chaining or backward chaining [1]. Expert systems can also employ neural networks and fuzzy logic for knowledge representation and reasoning [1]. The evolution of definitions for expert systems has been recorded across publications. Early research established their viability, and since then, various commercial systems have been developed to demonstrate their use in real environments [1]. The limitations currently are building expert systems with deep knowledge rather than heuristic and empirical knowledge [1]. Inductive learning is used in neural network expert systems to prevent the knowledge acquisition bottleneck [1]. References:
